subject: Fix for CooperativeReader to process read length

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 1:

Would be nice to see a test for this
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

Thanks Ben. I've added some extra tests to test_utils to verify this particular "read-size" compliant behaviour. This should be enough.

Testing the actual bug requires swift interaction, so it cannot be test functionally here. We may think about adding appropriate test scenario to Tempest, but it will require generating large (>5Gb) image file for testing, which may be an overhead.

Patch Set 6:

Looks better now. I think there could be a test on LimitExceeded, but it would eat 128mb of memory, which is pretty insane :)

Patch Set 6:

Mike, yeah: testing that would either require some hacking to override the limit constant or will really require generating >128 Megs of data, which will abuse zuul

Patch Set 6:

I had a go at an alternative approach. Interested to know what people think.

Basically it's this:

 diff --git a/glance_store/_drivers/http.py b/glance_store/_drivers/http.py
 index 7a8ec94..e8c4981 100644
 --- a/glance_store/_drivers/http.py
 +++ b/glance_store/_drivers/http.py
 @@ -139,6 +139,7 @@ class Store(glance_store.driver.Store):
                     return ''
 
 -        return (ResponseIndexable(iterator, content_length), content_length)
 +        return (resp, content_length)
 
     def get_schemes(self):
         return ('http', 'https')



'ResponseIndexible' was added with this change:
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/4096/

To address:

   Impedence between the representation returned by Store.get() and
    the implicit requirements of Store.add() required careful iterator/
    filelike wrapping.

Now that Store.add does it's own wrapping it looks to me like ResponseIndexible may not be required -- at least not for it's original purpose.

With this change CooperativeReader will access the read of the underlying fd in this case.

I functionally tested this and it seemed to work for the 'swift_store_large_object_size' reproducer.

I haven't thought too much about corner cases (or glance_store 'correctness') etc yet.
Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Patch Set 6:

Update on the alternative approach.

Turns out you get a 0 size image when downloading in the normal way from the regualar http store (ie when not using copy-from). Not good!

What httplib (used by the http store) returns for a request body is not an iterator, so it is incompatible with the format that wsgi expects.

We don't his this when using the 'raw' stream from swift client (I did a check) because the 'requests' library (ie not httplib) can return something you can iterate over.

A quick experimental hack to replace httplib with requests for the 'get' when using the http store:

    def get(self, location, offset=0, chunk_size=None, context=None):
        """
        Takes a `glance_store.location.Location` object that indicates
        where to find the image file, and returns a tuple of generator
        (for reading the image file) and image_size

        :param location `glance_store.location.Location` object, supplied
                        from glance_store.location.get_location_from_uri()
        """
        import requests
        url = "%s://%s%s" % (location.store_location.scheme, location.store_location.netloc, location.store_location.path)
        self.request_session = requests.Session()
        resp = self.request_session.request('GET', url)
        return (resp, resp.headers['content-length'])

worked for both the copy-from and standard download cases when 

Obviously we'd need to be careful and this would require more work.

Probably too intrusive to fix this bug -- but in the long run it might be the way to go.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks Alex
